title: Psalms Chapter 80 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 80 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 80 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 80.

questions.question: Who is addressed as the Shepherd of Israel in Psalms 80?
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: Psalms 80:1 calls upon the Shepherd of Israel, referring to God who leads Joseph like a flock.

questions.question: Which three tribes are mentioned in Psalms 80:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Ephraim, Benjamin, and Manasseh
questions.explanation: Psalms 80:2 specifically mentions Ephraim, Benjamin, and Manasseh as part of the plea for God's strength.

questions.question: What does the psalmist ask God to do in Psalms 80:3?
options: Turn us again and cause thy face to shine
questions.correctAnswer: Turn us again and cause thy face to shine
questions.explanation: The psalmist asks God to turn them again and cause His face to shine so they shall be saved, as stated in Psalms 80:3.

questions.question: According to Psalms 80:5, what has God fed the people?
questions.correctAnswer: Bread of tears
questions.explanation: Psalms 80:5 says that God fed the people with the bread of tears and gave them tears to drink in great measure.

questions.question: What effect does the psalm say the people have on their neighbors in Psalms 80:6?
options: They are a strife unto their neighbors
They are beloved by their neighbors
They are ignored by their neighbors
questions.correctAnswer: They are a strife unto their neighbors
questions.explanation: Psalms 80:6 states that the people have become a strife to their neighbors and their enemies laugh among themselves.

questions.question: What is the vine in Psalms 80 described as being brought out of?
questions.correctAnswer: Egypt
questions.explanation: Psalms 80:8 says that God brought a vine out of Egypt, casting out the heathen and planting it.

questions.question: What is said to have covered the hills in Psalms 80:10?
questions.correctAnswer: The shadow of the vine
questions.explanation: Psalms 80:10 describes the hills being covered with the shadow of the vine whose boughs were like goodly cedars.

questions.question: Where did the vine send out its boughs according to Psalms 80:11?
options: Unto the sea and unto the river
questions.correctAnswer: Unto the sea and unto the river
questions.explanation: Psalms 80:11 states that the vine sent out her boughs unto the sea and her branches unto the river.

questions.question: What has happened to the hedge of the vine in Psalms 80:12?
questions.correctAnswer: It has been broken down
questions.explanation: Psalms 80:12 asks why God has broken down the hedge so that everyone passing by plucks the vine.

questions.question: What animals are said to waste and devour the vine in Psalms 80?
questions.correctAnswer: Boar and wild beast
questions.explanation: Psalms 80:13 says the boar out of the wood doth waste it, and the wild beast of the field doth devour it.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 80:4 asks how long God will be angry against the prayer of His people.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 80:4 explicitly questions how long God will be angry against the prayer of His people.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 80:17 asks for God's hand to be upon the man of His right hand.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 80:17 requests that God's hand be upon the man of His right hand, the son of man made strong for Himself.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 80:19 says that by God causing His face to shine, they shall be saved.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 80:19 confirms that when God causes His face to shine, the people shall be saved.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 80:18: 'So will not we go back from thee: quicken us, and we will call upon thy ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: name
questions.explanation: Psalms 80:18 says, 'So will not we go back from thee: quicken us, and we will call upon thy name.'

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 80:15: 'And the vineyard which thy right hand hath ______, and the branch that thou madest strong for thyself.'
questions.correctAnswer: planted
questions.explanation: Psalms 80:15 refers to the vineyard which thy right hand hath planted and the branch made strong for thyself.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 80 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 80 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 80, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God during hardship?
options: God is our Shepherd who leads and saves us.
We should rely only on our own strength.
Trials mean God has abandoned us.
We must isolate ourselves during hardship.
questions.correctAnswer: God is our Shepherd who leads and saves us.
questions.explanation: Psalms 80:1 describes God as the Shepherd who leads Joseph like a flock, and verses 2-3 encourage turning to God for salvation and strength. This teaches trust in God's guidance and care during difficulties.

questions.question: How does Psalms 80 teach about the importance of persistent prayer in the life of a believer?
options: Persistent prayer pleases God and brings restoration.
Prayer should be brief and infrequent.
We should pray only when things are good.
questions.correctAnswer: Persistent prayer pleases God and brings restoration.
questions.explanation: Verse 4 questions how long God will be angry at the prayers of His people, and verses 7 and 19 repeatedly ask God to turn and shine His face, showing persistent prayer as a path to restoration.

questions.question: Based on Psalms 80, what does the imagery of the vine symbolize in relation to God's people and their spiritual life?
options: The vine represents God's nurturing and planting of His people.
The vine is a symbol of worldly wealth.
The vine shows the need for isolation from others.
The vine represents human strength alone.
questions.correctAnswer: The vine represents God's nurturing and planting of His people.
questions.explanation: Verses 8-11 describe God bringing a vine out of Egypt, planting it, and causing it to grow strong, symbolizing His care and establishment of His people.

questions.question: A believer feels discouraged because of spiritual attacks from others. What biblical truth about God's protection can you share from Psalms 80?
options: Though enemies cause strife, God is still the protector who can restore us.
We must fight enemies alone without God’s help.
Spiritual attacks mean we should give up our faith.
questions.correctAnswer: Though enemies cause strife, God is still the protector who can restore us.
questions.explanation: Verse 6 notes enemies laugh and cause strife, but repeated pleas in verses 7, 14, and 19 ask God to return and save, showing that God’s protection and restoration are assured.

questions.question: How does Psalms 80 encourage humility and dependence on God in times of loss or destruction?
options: By acknowledging that the vineyard is burned and cut down and asking God to return.
By blaming others for all problems.
By relying on human wisdom alone.
questions.correctAnswer: By acknowledging that the vineyard is burned and cut down and asking God to return.
questions.explanation: Verse 16 admits the vineyard is burned and cut down, while verses 14 and 19 beseech God to return and restore, teaching humility and dependence on God’s mercy.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 80 teaches that God’s face shining upon His people results in their salvation and renewal.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verses 3, 7, and 19 repeatedly state that when God causes His face to shine, the people shall be saved, emphasizing God's favor as the key to salvation.

questions.question: True or False: The Psalmist asks God to strengthen the 'man of thy right hand' who was made strong for God’s purpose.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 17 specifically requests God’s hand to be upon the man of His right hand, the son of man made strong by God, demonstrating reliance on divine strength.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 80 describes God as the Shepherd of Israel who leads Joseph like a _______.
questions.correctAnswer: flock
questions.explanation: Verse 1 refers to God as the Shepherd who leads Joseph like a flock, illustrating His care and guidance for His people.

questions.question: What practical lesson about forgiveness and reconciliation can be drawn from the repeated plea in Psalms 80:7 and 19 to "Turn us again, O God of hosts"?
options: We should seek God’s restoration and forgiveness continually.
We should hold grudges and avoid reconciliation.
We only need to seek God once.
Forgiveness is unnecessary if we feel justified.
questions.correctAnswer: We should seek God’s restoration and forgiveness continually.
questions.explanation: The repeated plea to God to turn and restore shows a humility and willingness to seek forgiveness and reconciliation persistently.

questions.question: In terms of spiritual discipline, what does Psalms 80 teach about recognizing God's anger and responding appropriately?
options: Recognize God’s anger as a call to repentance and prayer.
Ignore God's anger and continue sinning.
Stop praying if God is angry.
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize God’s anger as a call to repentance and prayer.
questions.explanation: Verse 4 speaks of God's anger against the prayers of His people, implying the need for repentance and persistent prayer to restore fellowship.

questions.question: How does Psalms 80 model a biblical work ethic and stewardship through the metaphor of the vine?
options: By showing God’s cultivation and care for the vine, teaching us to nurture what God entrusts.
By emphasizing self-reliance without God’s help.
questions.correctAnswer: By showing God’s cultivation and care for the vine, teaching us to nurture what God entrusts.
questions.explanation: Verses 8-11 depict God planting the vine and preparing room for it to take root, highlighting the importance of stewardship and care over what God has given.

questions.question: What does Psalms 80 teach about the role of community and fellowship when facing external opposition?
options: The community should turn together to God for help and restoration.
Ignore the community and only focus on self.
questions.correctAnswer: The community should turn together to God for help and restoration.
questions.explanation: The plural language such as "us" and "we" in verses 2, 3, 7, and 19 shows communal prayer and dependence on God in adversity.

questions.question: How does Psalms 80 illustrate the importance of gratitude and contentment despite suffering?
options: By acknowledging tears and suffering but still calling on God for salvation.
By blaming others for our troubles.
questions.correctAnswer: By acknowledging tears and suffering but still calling on God for salvation.
questions.explanation: Verse 5 speaks of being fed with the bread of tears and given tears to drink, yet the Psalmist prays for God's shining face and salvation, demonstrating grateful dependence.

questions.question: According to Psalms 80, what is the consequence of God withdrawing His favor from His people, and what should their response be?
options: The people perish at God’s rebuke and should pray for His return.
They should rely on their own power.
questions.correctAnswer: The people perish at God’s rebuke and should pray for His return.
questions.explanation: Verse 16 states that the vineyard is burned and cut down, perishing at God’s rebuke, and verses 14 and 19 plead for God’s return, teaching humility and prayer.

questions.question: How does Psalms 80 encourage believers to maintain integrity and honesty in their prayers and relationship with God?
options: By honestly expressing their distress and asking God for restoration.
By hiding their sins from God.
questions.correctAnswer: By honestly expressing their distress and asking God for restoration.
questions.explanation: The Psalm expresses raw emotions of anger, tears, and loss (verses 4-6) while honestly pleading for God’s help, modeling honesty in prayer.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 80 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 80.

questions.question: In Psalms 80, the 'Shepherd of Israel' is asked to lead Joseph like a flock. Which Old Testament figure is symbolized by Joseph in this context?
questions.correctAnswer: Joseph
questions.explanation: Psalm 80:1 specifically mentions 'thou that leadest Joseph like a flock,' indicating Joseph as a symbol of the tribes of Israel, reflecting the historical patriarch Joseph.

questions.question: Which three tribes of Israel are explicitly mentioned in Psalms 80 as being before God for salvation?
questions.correctAnswer: Ephraim, Benjamin, Manasseh
questions.explanation: Psalm 80:2 names these three tribes as representatives of Israel asking God to stir up His strength and save them.

questions.question: What metaphor does Psalm 80 use to describe Israel's condition under enemies, which also foreshadows prophetic imagery in Isaiah and Ezekiel?
options: Israel as a vine broken and plucked
questions.correctAnswer: Israel as a vine broken and plucked
questions.explanation: Verses 8-12 use the vine metaphor to describe Israel’s planting, growth, and subsequent devastation, a theme echoed in Isaiah 5 and Ezekiel 15.

questions.question: The phrase 'bread of tears' in Psalms 80:5 is an example of what literary device?
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor
questions.explanation: Psalm 80:5 uses 'bread of tears' metaphorically to describe sustained sorrow and suffering experienced by God's people.

questions.question: According to Psalms 80, what effect does the anger of God have on His people as described in verse 6?
options: They become a strife unto neighbors and enemies laugh
questions.correctAnswer: They become a strife unto neighbors and enemies laugh
questions.explanation: Psalm 80:6 explains that God's anger causes the people to be a source of conflict with neighbors and a subject of mockery by enemies.

questions.question: The recurring plea 'Turn us again, O God of hosts, and cause thy face to shine' in Psalms 80 is an example of which Hebrew poetic feature?
questions.correctAnswer: Refrain
questions.explanation: The repeated plea in verses 3, 7, and 19 serves as a refrain, a common feature in Hebrew Psalms to emphasize urgent petition.

questions.question: In Psalms 80:8-11, the 'vine' is said to have been brought out of Egypt and planted. What historical event does this allude to in Israel's history?
questions.correctAnswer: The Exodus from Egypt
questions.explanation: The vine being brought out of Egypt (Psalm 80:8) alludes to the Exodus, symbolizing God's deliverance and the establishment of Israel in the Promised Land.

questions.question: Which imagery in Psalms 80 portrays the enemies as wild animals devastating the vineyard?
options: A boar out of the wood and wild beasts of the field
A raven flying over the field
questions.correctAnswer: A boar out of the wood and wild beasts of the field
questions.explanation: Psalm 80:13 uses the metaphor of a boar and wild beasts to depict how enemies ravage God's people.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalm 80 calls upon God to 'look down from heaven, and behold, and visit this ____.'
questions.correctAnswer: vine
questions.explanation: Psalm 80:14 pleads for God to look down and visit the vine, symbolizing Israel.

questions.question: Who is referred to as the 'man of thy right hand' in Psalms 80:17, which is often interpreted messianically in Christian theology?
questions.correctAnswer: The son of man
questions.explanation: Psalm 80:17 mentions 'the man of thy right hand, upon the son of man,' a phrase later associated with the Messiah in the New Testament.

questions.question: What is the primary request repeatedly made to God throughout Psalm 80?
options: To turn again and cause His face to shine
questions.correctAnswer: To turn again and cause His face to shine
questions.explanation: The repeated plea in verses 3, 7, and 19 asks God to turn back to His people and shine His face upon them to bring salvation.

questions.question: True or False: Psalm 80 describes God as dwelling 'between the cherubims,' a phrase that connects to the Ark of the Covenant imagery.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalm 80:1 explicitly states God dwells 'between the cherubims,' referring to the mercy seat of the Ark of the Covenant in the Tabernacle and Temple.

questions.question: The phrase 'bread of tears' and 'tears to drink' in Psalms 80:5 can be understood as a typology of which New Testament experience?
questions.correctAnswer: The suffering of Christ
questions.explanation: The metaphor of sorrow and suffering in Psalm 80:5 prefigures the passion and suffering of Christ portrayed in the New Testament.

questions.question: Psalm 80 emphasizes God’s anger against the prayers of His people. Which theme in prophetic literature does this align with?
options: Divine judgment and call for repentance
questions.correctAnswer: Divine judgment and call for repentance
questions.explanation: Psalm 80:4's lament about God's anger aligns with prophetic themes of judgment that calls the people to repent and return to God.

questions.question: In the ancient Near Eastern context, the vine in Psalm 80 symbolizes what aspect of Israel’s identity?
questions.correctAnswer: National prosperity and divine favor
questions.explanation: The vine metaphor in verses 8-11 reflects Israel’s flourishing under God’s planting, symbolizing national prosperity and favor in the ancient Near East.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 80 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 80 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Psalms 80, how is God depicted in relation to Israel, emphasizing His leadership and protective role?
options: As the Shepherd of Israel who leads Joseph like a flock
As a distant king who watches from afar
As a warrior who fights with physical weapons
As a judge who only punishes Israel
questions.correctAnswer: As the Shepherd of Israel who leads Joseph like a flock
questions.explanation: Psalms 80:1 calls God the 'Shepherd of Israel' who leads Joseph like a flock, highlighting His pastoral care and guidance. This is consistent with John 10:11 where Jesus calls Himself the Good Shepherd, Ezekiel 34:11-12 where God promises to search for His sheep, and Isaiah 40:11 emphasizing God’s tender care.

questions.question: What is the significance of God dwelling 'between the cherubims' as mentioned in Psalms 80:1?
options: It signifies God's presence in the holy of holies, symbolizing His holiness and majesty
It means God is confined to the temple and cannot act outside
It indicates God is only concerned with angelic beings
It suggests that God is limited to a physical location
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies God's presence in the holy of holies, symbolizing His holiness and majesty
questions.explanation: The phrase 'between the cherubims' (Psalms 80:1) refers to God's presence in the holy of holies, representing His divine majesty and holiness. This is paralleled in Exodus 25:22 where God promises to meet Moses between the cherubim, and in Hebrews 9:5 where the cherubim are described as part of the mercy seat symbolizing God's presence and covenant.

questions.question: Which tribes are invoked in Psalms 80:2 as representative of the whole nation for God’s saving intervention?
questions.correctAnswer: Ephraim, Benjamin, and Manasseh
questions.explanation: Psalms 80:2 mentions Ephraim, Benjamin, and Manasseh, the main tribes representing the northern and southern divisions of Israel, indicating a plea for national restoration. This aligns with Genesis 48:8-20 where Ephraim and Manasseh are blessed, and Judges 20:1 where Benjamin is a key tribe, reflecting the unity of God’s people.

questions.question: What does the Psalmist request God to do repeatedly in Psalms 80 to bring salvation to Israel?
options: Turn again and cause His face to shine
Send fire to consume their enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Turn again and cause His face to shine
questions.explanation: The Psalmist repeatedly petitions God to 'turn us again' and 'cause thy face to shine' (Psalms 80:3, 7, 19), symbolizing divine favor and restoration. This concept echoes Numbers 6:25-26, where God's face shining is a blessing, and 2 Corinthians 3:18, where believers reflect God’s glory, indicating salvation and renewal.

questions.question: How does Psalms 80 describe the spiritual and communal condition of Israel under God's anger in verses 5 and 6?
options: They are fed with the bread of tears and become a strife to their neighbors
They are victorious and prosperous over their enemies
They experience peace and unity among neighbors
They are exalted and praised by all nations
questions.correctAnswer: They are fed with the bread of tears and become a strife to their neighbors
questions.explanation: Psalms 80:5-6 describes Israel’s suffering under God's displeasure as being fed with 'the bread of tears' and becoming a source of conflict, with enemies laughing. This aligns with Lamentations 3:19-24 on suffering, and Romans 8:22 describing creation’s groaning, emphasizing the reality of judgment and hardship due to sin.

questions.question: What metaphor is used in Psalms 80 to describe Israel’s nation and its spiritual state?
options: A vine brought out of Egypt and planted
A strong fortress on a hill
A mighty river flowing to the sea
A burning bush that is not consumed
questions.correctAnswer: A vine brought out of Egypt and planted
questions.explanation: In Psalms 80:8-11, Israel is metaphorically described as a vine brought out of Egypt and planted by God, symbolizing His covenantal care and Israel’s growth. This metaphor is consistent with John 15:1-5 where Jesus calls Himself the true vine, and Isaiah 5:1-7 where Israel is portrayed as a vineyard requiring God’s care.

questions.question: What calamity has befallen the 'vine' in Psalms 80:12-13, symbolizing Israel’s distress?
options: Its hedges are broken down and it is wasted by wild beasts
It has been flooded and drowned by the river
It has been scorched by the sun without rain
It is overgrown and choked by thorns
questions.correctAnswer: Its hedges are broken down and it is wasted by wild beasts
questions.explanation: Psalms 80:12-13 describes the vine’s hedges being broken down and it being wasted by a boar and wild beasts, symbolizing Israel's vulnerability to enemies and chaos. This imagery parallels Hosea 10:1 and Jeremiah 2:21, where Israel’s protection is removed, exposing it to destruction.

questions.question: What plea is made in Psalms 80:14-15 regarding God’s relationship to the vine and vineyard He planted?
options: To look down from heaven, visit the vine, and restore it
To uproot the vine and plant a new one
To let the vine perish as a sign of judgment
To abandon the vineyard to its fate
questions.correctAnswer: To look down from heaven, visit the vine, and restore it
questions.explanation: In Psalms 80:14-15, the Psalmist beseeches God to look down from heaven and visit the vine and vineyard, expressing a request for divine restoration. This reflects God’s covenant faithfulness seen in Isaiah 27:2-5 and Jeremiah 31:12, emphasizing hope for redemption despite judgment.

questions.question: According to Psalms 80:16-17, what consequences have come upon the vine and what is requested for 'the man of thy right hand'?
options: The vine is burned and cut down; God’s hand is requested upon the strong man He made
The vine is flourishing; the man is asked to be humble
The vine is ignored; the man is asked to leave
The vine is replanted elsewhere; the man is to lead the enemies
questions.correctAnswer: The vine is burned and cut down; God’s hand is requested upon the strong man He made
questions.explanation: Psalms 80:16-17 states the vine is burned and cut down, reflecting judgment, and the Psalmist asks for God’s hand upon the man of His right hand, symbolizing God’s chosen leader or Messiah. This aligns with Psalm 110:1 and Isaiah 41:10 where God’s right hand denotes strength and favor.

questions.question: What is the response of the people in Psalms 80:18 if God grants restoration and life?
options: They will not turn back from God but will call upon His name
They will build new altars for idols
They will abandon worship and rely on their own strength
They will hide from God’s presence
questions.correctAnswer: They will not turn back from God but will call upon His name
questions.explanation: Psalms 80:18 expresses a commitment that if God revives them, they will not retreat but will call on His name, reflecting repentance and faith. This is consistent with Joel 2:32, Romans 10:13, and Jeremiah 29:13 regarding calling on the Lord for salvation.

questions.question: What repeated theological theme in Psalms 80 highlights God's role in salvation and restoration?
options: God’s turning again to His people and causing His face to shine
God’s silence and absence from His people
questions.correctAnswer: God’s turning again to His people and causing His face to shine
questions.explanation: The repeated refrain in Psalms 80 (verses 3, 7, 19) about God turning again and causing His face to shine underscores the necessity of God’s gracious intervention for salvation. This motif is echoed in Numbers 6:25, Psalm 31:16, and 2 Corinthians 4:6, emphasizing God’s mercy and active role in redemption.

questions.question: How does Psalms 80 portray the relationship between God’s judgment and the community’s suffering?
options: God’s anger results in tears, conflict, and enemies rejoicing over Israel
God’s judgment is mild and unnoticed
The community suffers despite God’s blessing
Suffering is unrelated to God’s actions
questions.correctAnswer: God’s anger results in tears, conflict, and enemies rejoicing over Israel
questions.explanation: Verses 4-6 describe God’s anger leading to Israel’s suffering—tears, strife with neighbors, and enemies laughing. This corresponds with Deuteronomy 28:15-68 on curses for disobedience and Lamentations 3:1-33 on the consequences of divine wrath, highlighting the covenantal consequences of sin.

questions.question: Which Christological theme can be inferred from the request in Psalms 80:17 to strengthen 'the son of man'?
options: A messianic plea for the strengthening of God's anointed representative
A call for a political leader to overthrow enemies
A request for the people to empower themselves
A reference to a pagan king
questions.correctAnswer: A messianic plea for the strengthening of God's anointed representative
questions.explanation: The phrase 'son of man' in Psalms 80:17 and the request for God's hand upon him is understood messianically, pointing to Christ as the anointed one empowered by God. This is supported by Daniel 7:13-14’s messianic 'Son of Man' and the New Testament’s application in Luke 22:69 and John 1:51.

questions.question: How does Psalms 80 use the imagery of fire and cutting down in verse 16 to communicate God's judgment?
options: It symbolizes destruction caused by God's rebuke and loss of favor
It refers to purification and refining only
It celebrates a victorious burning of enemies
It indicates a natural disaster unrelated to God
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes destruction caused by God's rebuke and loss of favor
questions.explanation: Verse 16 speaks of the vine burned with fire and cut down, symbolizing judgment and the consequences of God's rebuke. This imagery parallels Isaiah 5:6 and Jeremiah 12:10 where fire represents God's judgment and destruction upon sin, showing the serious consequences of divine wrath.

questions.question: What doctrinal truth is underscored by the Psalmist’s repeated appeal for God to 'shine forth' His face upon Israel?
options: God’s grace and presence are essential for salvation and restoration
God’s glory is only a future hope with no present effect
Salvation depends solely on human effort
God’s face shining means His judgment alone
questions.correctAnswer: God’s grace and presence are essential for salvation and restoration
questions.explanation: The repeated appeal for God to cause His face to shine (Psalms 80:3,7,19) highlights the necessity of God’s gracious presence for salvation. This truth is affirmed in Numbers 6:25-26, Psalm 31:16, and 2 Corinthians 4:6, where God's favor is the source of life and deliverance.
